Topic.Title: who trusts android with

Message.Msg: GOOD POINT: Android is inherently insecure. Because Android is made from open-source code Java, plus Android itself the entire Code/Software has been given by GOOG to about 20 different companies in many different countries. Thus China's CIA and N. Korea's CIA and IRAN's version of CIA all have the ANDROID CODE. Vs. there's only 1 company in the world that has the IOS Software Code, and that's Apple. Therefore, Android is always going to be more vulnerable to being hacked, to viruses, to stealing passwords and data.

Message.Title: Change in Apple's CAPITAL STRUCTURE (Apple should copy)
Message.Msg: Apple should Copy IBM and GOOG. Two companies who's stock prices are alot higher PEs. Apple should float some Debt, at today's super-low interest rates. It could sell 10 year debt at 2.4%, after-tax that would cost Apple 1.8%, and use say $50 billion of such to buy back shares, thereby saving money vs. even just the dividend it must pay on the shares, and also Apple would make an added 10 - 30% per year by owning the shares (yield of the stock, being inverse of the PE + growth). Thus Apple buying back its own shares ALOT MORE INTELLIGENT THAN EINHORN's AGITATING FOR BIGGER DIVIDEND.

Message.Title: TIm Cook is Deaf When It Comes to Shareholders
Message.Msg: Tim Cook fails to realize that this is not his company it the shareholders company. He works for them and by implication, their interests. Apple has traditionally been a close to the vest company. However, when a once high flying stock drops about 250 points and loses billions upon billions of market value its time to do something. Telling us you have a great pipeline and many new horizons to conquer simply does not cut it when you shares have taken such a pounding. When you do something and it suddenly does not work any more you need to adapt or fall by the wayside. Unfortunately the market is watching as Apple refuses to change their corporate culture to adjust to market forces and we are seeing that in the price of the stock. Tim Cook may be a great CEO but his failing the primary test of any CEO to protect and enrich shareholder value.

Topic.Title: what to do with apple shares

Message.Msg: Hi, from a fundamental point of view, AAPL looks cheap, from a psycholigical point of view, that the problem : because people know. its cheap, they dont give up and so we wait and wait for capitulation, and as far as I saw in the last decades, a capitulation is always needed for a healthy going-up again. but ther would be other possibilities too : you could sell covered calls, 1 ( 100 AAPL ) for 500 and 1 ( 100 AAPL ) for 550, so you would get out without loss on the stock and have earned the premium and if they expire useless, the premium would have reduced your 525-buying price and you could sell covered calls again. And you also could sell puts ( as much as you want to put on risk ) f.e. for a striking price of 400. So if it goes down to 400 you would have to take the AAPLs for 400, but have also earned the premium and would be happy, not having bought at 450 ( but this is only a solution, if you believ in AAPL long side over time and if you have enough money to risk in speculative business in general ) If you simply want to buy or sell and not consider options, I would buy or sell just half or a quarter of what you are willing to buy or sell and buy or sell the next fraction at the next price ( like 425 or 475 ). f.e. if it goes up from now ( which I do not think ) you could sell 25 at 450, 25 at 475, 25 at 500 a.s.o. ant at the end of the selling period, you still have a win. Similar, when it goes down and down, because when noone believes it any more, it will rise again and than you can fractionally sell you lower bought positions. Its a desperate situation being caught in a position with a loss, and if a position goes into the wrong way, you should take the loss fast ( which can also be wrong, if it just turns around the next moment, but if you are caught and do want to fight it out, you will need a lot of time to get the problems solved. But with AAPL, i think it could make sense, as everything around the company now is so negative. Even owning to much money now is a problem - I wish, I could have that one ..... Just my 2 cents and dont take anything from the above as an advice, just my thoughts about your question - if I would be right, I just could follow my ideas and be the richest man soon, but I am not ....

Topic.Title: It Was Over When Cue and Mansfield Insiders Sold $28M Nov 29 2012 at $583

Message.Msg: While your insider selling comments could be a signal to sell (a little late now), your assertion that $590 a share is pie in the sky is based on nothing. Given a normal valuation for a company still growing market share, revenues & EPS, the share price can easily eclipse $590. All it needs is the market sentiment to change to positive. The current price suggests that Apple is dead in the water. Positve news is being dismissed whereas the smallest negative rumor is jumped on by the media in such a manner that it is impacting the stock price. The stock is snow trading at about 3 times cash and a P/E under 10 if you pretend there is no cash. If Apple traded at the same P/E multiple as Microsoft, the current price would be $674. If it traded at the same multiple as Google, the price would be $1095. I won't even try to figure out the value if you use Amazon or Netflix's multiples as those stocks are too overpriced.

Topic.Title: You wonder if the company really was all Jobs with Johnson struggling, Cook struggling, Forstall gone...

Message.Msg: Sure, but the last big run up in Apple stock took place while Cook was CEO after Jobs death. It peaked at just above 700, and its roughly were it was when he took over. You are letting the short term swings in stock price be the judge of management performance. Was Cook the greatest manager ever when the price was at 700? Probably not. Well, same goes for the stock at 450, he's not the worst manager either.

Topic.Title: You wonder if the company really was all Jobs with Johnson struggling, Cook struggling, Forstall gone...

Message.Msg: For one, Tim Cook is a supply genius. Or porported supply guru. Nearly every product released over the past 6 months has been met with supply issues. Facts are facts, it held up Iphone 5 sales during the past quarter. For the first two months, October and November, there was a wait. That hurts results. End of story. Two, Cook has been atrocious in dealing with the media and investment community. His conferences and annual meeting are weak. He doesnt command the same stage that Jobs did. He uses childish terms like #$%$" and "silly" to describe products or investors. Three, he hasnt inked China Mobile yet. This was supposed to be inked late last year or early this year. We are now a quarter deep, tick tock. Four, I really do not care what the sell-side has been estimating on consensus. The company has missed the past three quarters. They might miss this quarter too. Listen, I get it, the sell-side's expectations are nuts. But they were nuts with Jobs too and he creamed results. Lastly, the street has spoken, this stock is getting pounded during one of the best broader market rallies in years. It's telling

Message.Title: Apple is working on search
Message.Msg: If you want to sell something it helps if the people you are trying to sell to have money and are willing to pay for value. BTW the two go hand in hand, people with money will always pay for value. Costco wholesale has the highest average income per customer than any other large scale retail operator. Apples IOS has the highest average income per user than any other mobile platform. By far. If I want to sell something of value at a price that I too can make a decent profit, I want to be in Costco and IOS. Apple is working on search. They will eventually attack right at the heart of Google. When that happens, the great subsidization machine that is Google search will slow dramatically. We will find out how much Googlers are willing to pay in a world were Google cant give it for free anymore.

Topic.Title: You wonder if the company really was all Jobs with Johnson struggling, Cook struggling, Forstall gone...

Message.Msg: How is Apple the company struggling? They are making record profits. The stock has been broken but that has more to do with the whims of Wall Street than anything else. Cook has been running Apple for the past two years as Jobs stepped down in January 2011. The past two years have been the company's best years ever. And they were even more remarkable when you consider that Apple transitioned from being a computer company to a mobile device company without any growing pains. Jobs had been battling cancer for the last years of his life. His role in the company for those years has been grossly overstated. Of course, he was a very talented guy but his greatest talent was in taking credit for others work. Jony Ive is far more responsible for Apple's success over the past few years yet he still is rarely mentioned. Apple's biggest differentiater has been design and that has been all Ive and his group. At some point in the near future Apple will announce a large buy back. At that point the downward momentum on the stock price will reverse and the stock should rise again. Until then, though, I guess it will be crazy season.

Topic.Title: You wonder if the company really was all Jobs with Johnson struggling, Cook struggling, Forstall gone...

Message.Msg: Yes ...Supply issues were a big problem no doubt ...but perhaps much of the problem comes from Apple's legal mess with Samsung who cut Apples supplies and raised prices sending Apple scrambling for new suppliers. What did Apple think Samsung would do? Plus There still are issues with Foxconn who were messing up production....scratching cases...plus Having one Manufacturer who you have had many problems with is a huge issue.Apple Putting all its faith in Foxconn to deliver is a problem.....Foxconn came right out and said we can not produce the number of units Apple is requesting. This is a Huge Problem don't ya think? Apple needs to get smart and have a second manufacturer to ensure production numbers it is that simple. Very True Cook needs to be better.....on Supply...he is thinking to small which steve would of never done. So 100% true on #2 as far as #3 QCOM has just cracked the Compatibility issue between Apple and China Mobile's system....so Now Apple does have a chip and China Mobile will be added most likely end of 2013. So perhaps it is just eager investors wanting it sooner cause we have been hearing about China Mobile for such a long time with no results. 4: No breaks were given to Cook by The Media and Analysts.....After Jobs most thought Apple would fall apart without him .....Between Over zealous Analysts and Negative Media Blitz......hard to keep a stock up with investors hearing every second of day Apple is done. Missing The Hoilday Q by less then 300 million is a joke....but the lower guidance is what killed......The sandbagging has caught up to Apple......every Analyst expects a beat of X % over Apples LOw ball numbers......Still hard to think of 3 misses with a possible 4th on the way. Things will Change as it it much harder to Steer a Much Larger boat....Jobs Boat was not as large as it is today. Apple is still an Amazing company...there have been miss steps no doubt....But 137 plus Billion in cash....can not be so bad...... Sentiment will change......when Apple starts Saying something meaningful and revealing new product categories......All You say is Good and On Spot.....we just have to have a little more faith and know The stock will be going north soon......

Message.Title: Board Meeting NOT Shareholders' Meeting
Message.Msg: As I noted yesterday, too many people do not seem to understand that matters like dividends, buybacks, and certainly future products are not the kind of issues that are addressed at shareholders' meetings. A shareholders' meeting is to vote on items such as appointing an auditor (they did: E&Y) and other such business of corporate governance. However, I just saw a Bloomberg video in which Gamco Investors CIO Howard Ward noted that the Apple Board of Directors meet next week. THAT is when they will vote on a dividend and/or increase, or whatever else people may be hoping for, but I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for preferred shares or "iPrefs." As I also noted yesterday, in 2012, the initial dividend and buyback program was not announced at the shareholders' meeting in February, but rather in a press release on March 19, 2012. Most likely, that decision was made in a Board of Directors meeting during the week following the shareholders' meeting. Now they are doing the same thing. Expect an announcement in March.

Message.Msg: I just read some of TC's old earnings ... he's been the same all along. Boring and unwavering in staying true to Apple's quality and mission. The stock has been slammed in the past, though that was when Apple was unequivocally number one and Samsung was in the shadows. IMO, I say all longs take a deep breath. History will repeat itself. Apple will give a nice dividend increase/buyback announcement in March (TC wouldn't say they are having "very, very active discussions on cash" if he wasn't planning something significant); and more importantly, they will innovate. Apple doesn't have a #$%$-load of the best and brightest techies - with huge R&D budgets - sitting around just making smaller and bigger tablets or phones. With the dividend increase, the stock will go up to the high 400s to 500. With the next announcement, you will see a steady rise to 600. That said, if you're in for 600 or below, you are fine. Anything north of 600, then you need to hope and pray for iTV or some truly transformational innovation (as opposed to an iPhone mini). IMO, again, 575-600 by Jan 2014.

Message.Title: Unsold IPhones Piling Up at Leap Wireless
Message.Msg: For Leap Wireless, a big bet on the iPhone is becoming a big headache, Anton Troianovski reports on Markets Hub. Photo: Getty Images. For one of the country's prepaid cellphone carriers, a big bet on the iPhone is becoming a big headache. Leap Wireless International Inc., LEAP -2.88% which operates the Cricket cellphone brand, said it is on pace to sell half as many iPhones as it committed to sell during the first year of its contract with Apple Inc., AAPL +0.09% which ends in June. As a result, Leap said, it could end up with $100 million worth of unsold iPhones by the middle of this year. That spells more trouble for Leap, a company struggling to keep pace with larger competitors, and sheds light on the challenges facing Apple in cracking the huge market for smartphones being bought by lower-income consumers. But even on the high end, Apple is facing steep competition. Leap's Mr. Elliott said Apple faced strong competition from Samsung Electronics Co.'s 005930.SE +1.11% latest smartphone, the Galaxy S III. "I would say there was a stronger device in our lineup," he said, referring to the S III. A version of this article appeared February 28, 2013, on page B3 in the U.S. edition of The Wall Street Journal, with the headline: Leap Wireless Faces Worry on Big iPhone Bet.

Topic.Title: Unsold IPhones Piling Up at Leap Wireless

Message.Msg: They should just dump them on the open market. The prepaid playing field has shifted significantly now that Google has begun selling a contract-free Galaxy Nexus, and the iPhone has made its way to major prepaid providers. The long-term cost-savings of these phones and month-to-month plans are very compelling. If you can afford the full, upfront price of the smartphones, you can save hundreds of dollars over the life of a typical two-year contract. Let's launch the calculator app and take a closer look. A 16GB iPhone 4S will cost nearly $2,400 over two years with AT&T or Verizon. That includes the subsidized phone cost of $200, plus $90 per month for data, texting and 450 minutes. A subsidized Sprint iPhone 4S costs $200 and $80 per month for unlimited use; that's a 2-year total of a little more than $2,100. At Sprint-owned Virgin Mobile, you need to fork over full price for the iPhone 4S — $650. Yikes! But combine that with the $40 monthly plan — 1,200 minutes and unlimited text and data — and you'll spend just $1,610 over 24 months. If you can get by with the $30 monthly plan's 300 minutes, you're total cost drops to just $1,370. That's a cool $1,000 less than AT&T and Verizon. Virgin Mobile's unlimited $50 monthly plan for iPhone is somewhat less appealing at a 2-year cost of $1,850. Cricket Wireless offers one unlimited monthly plan for $55 and charges $500 for the iPhone 4S. That's a 2-year cost of $1,820. Cricket's iPhone should appeal to travelers because its SIM card is unlocked for international use. But there are other drawbacks. The Cricket iPhone is otherwise locked in the U.S. The Virgin Mobile iPhone is locked, too. That means if you stop monthly service, you'll need to get a new number to resume cellular service with a new carrier. Those unlimited data plans come with an asterisk, too. If you start burning over 2GB of data use, Cricket and Virgin Mobile will throttle you to painfully slow download speeds. And then there are the networks. Cricket is an independent company that relies on Sprint to fill in gaps on its own network. Virgin Mobile, of course, uses Sprint's nationwide network.

The hardware is fabulous, and will soon cover every consumer contingency.

Message.Title: Apple's Satellite Phone Patent Could Technically Apply to TV
Message.Msg: Apple's invention advantageously provides a method and system for achieving a link improvement in a diverse communication system such as a satellite-based system. The method and system include steps that result in the adjustment of timing offsets between mobile stations and the sharing or reallocation of timing misalignments among the diversity paths through the diverse satellite paths. Once the timing misalignments have been reallocated, various zoning and scheduling methods are employed in order to schedule the transmissions of various mobile stations within a common zone. Apple's invention is in relation to the mobile-to-satellite communication link, however, the techniques described in the patent filing are not restricted solely to this type of communication link, but may be applied to all RF communication links. The techniques, for example, can also be applied to the downlink direction, from the satellite to the mobile and in general to all communications links irrespective of the direction of the information transfer. Apple's patent is a very engineer focused and provides little in the way of actual applications that Apple may be thinking of beyond what we've presented. However, beyond the benefits of having a satellite phone for use off shore on cruise liners or when you're in remote areas such as the mountains, Apple could theoretically be thinking of using their satellite technology to delivery future movie and television services. That's the application that we'll be keeping our eye open for in future related patents regarding satellite technology. Apple may be low keying this invention but it packs quite the punch if you logically extend what it could mean for future services.

Message.Title: Foul Play! UK Judge who issued an Extreme Ruling for Samsung against Apple is now working for Samsung
Message.Msg: Irony Foul Play! UK Judge who issued an Extreme Ruling for Samsung against Apple is now working for Samsung Our friend Florian Mueller over at FOSS Patents has an interesting report out this morning. Mueller states that "By far and away the weirdest ruling in the worldwide smartphone and tablet wars came down last year in the UK, where a publicity order forcing Apple to promote Samsung's products and to make itself ridiculous in public was upheld by an appeals court, and where Apple's efforts to comply with the order were deemed "false and misleading". I thought Apple was being treated way too harshly because in the end it was just trying to defend its intellectual property rights in court and merely had refused to withdraw a German lawsuit after a UK ruling by a lower court." Mueller added "I wonder how certain people in Cupertino feel about it." Yes, this could be interesting. Will it mean challenging that ruling in favor of Samsung? Time will tell - but for now the general cry I'm hearing is: Off with his Head!

Message.Title: BOA Merill Lynch Swap Out Of Apple And Into Samsung On Lack Of Innovation @ MWC
Message.Msg: Samsung could be the new Apple, analysts say Matthew Braga | Feb 28, 2013 11:28 AM ET Samsung Electronics Co. could be on track to become the next Apple Inc., analysts say, pointing to a slew of new, “compelling” product announcements at Mobile World Congress (MWC) as proof of the iPhone maker’s declining penchant for innovation. In a report from Bank of America Merill Lynch released Thursday morning, analysts were intrigued by the “replacement of Apple by Samsung,” as Chinese device manufacturers such as Huawei Technology Co., Ltd. and ZTE Corp. now appear to be cribbing from the Samsung’s designs and feature sets instead. Samsung announced a number of new products at MWC, held annually in Barcelona, including the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 – the Korean electronics giant’s answer to the iPad Mini, released last year. “We believe Apple’s recent products, the iPhone 5 and the iPad Mini simply can’t stand next to the innovation and buzz Samsung has brought to the market,” the report reads. Merill Lynch analysts predicted that Samsung’s growing mobile busness, in addition to the strength of traditional businesses such as flash memory production and high-definition TVs, would translate into “solid earnings momentum” for investors.

On the one hand, we have actual shipping products from Apple that are critically acclaimed and selling in record numbers (and for record profits); on the other, a $1300 laptop that only runs a web browser and a HUD headset that will supposedly ship at the end of the year from Google. And this somehow shows that Apple is slumping.

Message.Title: Outages result in gray skies for iCloud users
Message.Msg: INFINITE LOOP / THE APPLE ECOSYSTEM Outages result in gray skies for iCloud users Document syncing, iCloud backups, or Photo Stream have been down for 7+ hours. by Jacqui Cheng - Feb 28 2013, 11:15pm LST Apple's System Status page offers some info, but no expectation of when the services will be back up. If you're a regular Photo Stream or Documents in the Cloud user, this morning's iCloud outage is probably already giving you hives. The entire service isn't down, but key parts of it are—users can still make use of Find My Friends, iTunes Match, and Contact, Calendar, Reminders, and Notes syncing, but iOS device backups, document syncing, and Photo Stream have been down for (as of this writing) almost seven hours and counting. Apple's System Status page, which was revamped last December to offer more information to users, shows that the three iCloud services have been down since just after 3am CST. Apple claims "less than 3%" of users are affected by this outage, though such a claim seems disingenuous—at the very least, there's a hefty portion of iPhone, iPod touch, and iPad users who back up their devices to the cloud, and tons of others sync documents over iCloud through various apps. (And, as noted by 9to5Mac earlier, some users on Twitter are reporting other iCloud services being down that Apple has not indicated on the status page.) iCloud outages are, unfortunately, nothing new. Still, they rarely last this long. There's no indication when these services will be back up; we've reached out for comment, but Apple has yet to respond. We'll update this article if we hear anything back.

Topic.Title: What else could possibly be spun on AAPL?

Message.Msg: I am not sure why you are asking me this, it is not like I have any special skill in gauging the stock market. If you want my opinion, though, it seems that the stock is broken. Everyone knows it is an insanely good value but the conventional wisdom is that broken stocks take a while to recover. That is why it is languishing where it is at. People are watching it and waiting to get back in. There has never been a beat down stock quite like Apple, though, and with $137B there is a lot it can do to change things. The new controller, Luca Maestri, starts work next week. He is a champion of returning value to shareholders so it is rather obvious a buyback is in the works. If Apple announces a $50B buyback that would mean they could purchase 1M shares a day for 100 days. That would go a long way to turning momentum around. With HFT and day trading dominating volume, I would imagine that only around 1-2M shares actually trades hands every day. So Apple scooping up all of those shares will get the stock moving quickly. After a few $5+ days the hedge funds that bailed and other momentum chasers will jump back in. And after spending only around $10B or so of the allocated funds the stock price will be back to a PE of around 13 or so, leaving Apple with enough cash to goose the stock price in case something like this ever happens again. Where Apple will be in a year is something I do not know. That will depend on just how much damage this barrage of negative publicity has done to sales. And whether phablets are really what consumers want or just a word that analysts love saying. I do think the PE will eventually decompress to around 13-14, though.

Message.Title: Apple To Defer $40 Billion Of Cash To Finance India Sales Says Jefferies Misek
Message.Msg: Analyst Peter Misek Thinks Next Two Years Will Be Rough Period For Apple According to Misek, Apple is about to face a very rough two-year period, and he might actually be right. In his note, Misek cites capital expenditures as one area of concern for Apple. The company’s capital expenditures are are likely to double in the next two years which would add about $10 billion per year in costs. The second worrisome area is Apple’s cash balance. Even though Apple has a boat load of cash, it could be reduced by $10 billion, and $40 billion of the cash could be deferred over the next two years as Apple sells pre-pay iPhones in India. That’s all complete speculation on Misek’s part though, but we do agree it might be hard to sell subsidized iPhones in India, so Apple might have to part with some of its cash pile to make it work. Misek also says the the rise of ‘whitebox smartphone sales’ will be troublesome for Apple. Companies like Glonee and Konka are offering handsets that are similar to the Samsung Galaxy S3, but a lot cheaper. Those phones will force Apple to invest in next-gen screen technology, but if Apple isn’t already investing in next-gen screen technology(which we’re sure they are) then they’re screwed for the next few years already.

Message.Title: Ecosystem
Message.Msg: CUPERTINO, California―February 28, 2013―Apple® today announced that iTunes U® content downloads have topped one billion. iTunes U features the world’s largest online catalog of free educational content from top schools and prominent libraries, museums and organizations helping educators create courses including lectures, assignments, books, quizzes and more for iOS users around the world. “It’s inspiring to see what educators and students of all types are doing with iTunes U,” said Eddy Cue, Apple’s senior vice president of Internet Software and Services. “With the incredible content offered on iTunes U, students can learn like never before―there are now iTunes U courses with more than 250,000 students enrolled in them, which is a phenomenal shift in the way we teach and learn.” More than 1,200 universities and colleges, and 1,200 K-12 schools and districts host over 2,500 public and thousands of private courses encompassing the arts, sciences, health and medicine, education, business and more. Leading universities including Duke, Yale, Cambridge, MIT and Oxford continue to extend their reach by enrolling more than 100,000 students in single iTunes U courses, with Stanford University and The Open University each surpassing 60 million content downloads. The Ohio State University’s Matthew “Dr. Fus” Stoltzfus’ General Chemistry course enrolled over 100,000 iTunes U students in the first year it was offered. “The interest my iTunes U course receives from non-college students is overwhelming,” said Professor Stoltzfus. “I’ve been working with high school teachers who use my iTunes U material to prepare to teach their own classes, high school students all over the world who are leveraging the course to tutor their fellow classmates, even retirees who download my iTunes U course to stay intellectually active.” Over 60 percent of iTunes U app downloads originate from outside the US, giving schools of any size the ability to share their content with a worldwide audience. The unmatched global reach of iTunes U gives educators, like University of California, Irvine Professor Dan Stokols, international recognition and acclaim in their fields. “Because of iTunes U, I have been able to introduce students and colleagues in China to research on the links between chronic multi-tasking, information overload and stress; discuss research publications and degree programs with students in Europe; and exchange information about the influence of neighborhood design on community levels of physical activity and obesity with students in Australia,” said Professor Stokols, whose Environmental Psychology course enrolls over 170,000 students on iTunes U. “The opportunity to impact so many students who are gaining interest in environmental psychology by taking my free course on iTunes U has been highly rewarding and gratifying for me as an educator and learner.” “I see success unfolding before me on a daily basis,” says Chrissy Boydstun, a teacher from Mansfield Independent School District in Texas which provides each of their over 10,000 high school students and faculty with an iPad®. “Students are engaged and working hard as they use the incredible amount of information at their fingertips in a way that is meaningful and impactful. I love the way iTunes U provides a roadmap to take students beyond what a typical lesson or lecture could achieve.” Educators can create iTunes U courses in 30 countries including recent additions: Brazil, South Korea, Turkey and United Arab Emirates. These courses, and other education content, can be accessed via the iTunes U app in 155 countries. In addition to thousands of individual iTunes U learning materials, over 75,000 educational apps are now available for iOS devices on the App Store℠. Additionally, with the free iBooks® Author app on the Mac® App Store, writers and publishers continue to bring ideas and stories to life sharing more than 10,000 original Multi-Touch™ books with the world.

Message.Title: Do people count things like AirPlay and iMatch as apple innovations?
Message.Msg: I ask because people keep on claiming that Apple hasn't innovated in a while and invariable they point to iPad and iPhone as if those are the only recent innovations. But I like to think of all the other things they do that work so well, like smart covers, iMessage, FaceTime, time machine, and iCloud. I know these aren't revolutionary things and I know Apple wasn't necessarily first to market, but they do help the average non technical person do things more easily. I remember watching the blackberry 10 unfailing and hearing people ooohhh and ahhhh over the ability to talk during a text message, and I couldn't help but wonder if people even appreciate that Apple was the first to truly deliver to the world the video phone with face time. I mean, an iPod touch for 200 dollars could ring just like a phone and a young grandson could have some face to face time with his grandmother, and it is as simple as picking up a telephone. It just works, but I suppose that that's not considered innovation. It's too bad because I really feel we should acknowledge when people or companies do a good job.

Message.Title: Four Apple Execs Got A Big Raise When Scott Forstall Was Canned
Message.Msg: Four Apple Execs Got A Big Raise When Scott Forstall Was Canned February 28, 2013 By Alyson Shontell Last year, Tim Cook fired long-time Apple executive and former mobile software chief, Scott Forstall. Forstall had led the Apple Maps team; it launched a disappointing product that was uncharacteristic of Apple, and Forstall paid the price. The hole Forstall left has been filled by four other executives, CFO Peter Oppenheimer, head of operations Jeff Williams, General Counsel Bruce Sewell and head of technology Bob Mansfield. The added territory came with a sizable raise for each. Wall Street Journal blogger Jessica Lessin scanned the company's proxy filing. She discovered each executive was given an additional $75,000 following Forstall's departure. The bump in pay was meant to "recognize the additional responsibilities assigned to the officers and to maintain internal equity,” according to the proxy. "In disclosing compensation for four of its senior vice presidents, the company said that it increased each executive’s base salary to $875,000 from $800,000 following the October changes to its executive team that were designed to encourage “even more collaboration between the Company’s hardware, software, and services teams,” Lessin writes.

Message.Title: Apple Lowers 2013 Legacy iPad Sales Guidance From 60m To 33m Units Says Analyst
Message.Msg: “Apple had planned to sell 40 million iPad minis and 60 million iPads in 2013,” said DisplaySearch analyst David Hsieh on the company’s blog. “However, the reality seems to be the reverse, as the iPad mini has been more popular than the iPad. We now understand that Apple may be planning to sell 55 million iPad minis and 33 million iPads in 2013.”

Topic.Title: Google Glasses will be bigger than expected.

Message.Msg: Before there ever was a Project Glass from Google, there was Apple's Glass Project in the form of a patent application filed in late 2006, published in 2008 and granted in 2009. Apple's Glass Project seemed to have fallen off the grid until July 2012 when a new patent application laid out some new parameters for their future glasses. The new glasses were being designed to work with augmented reality but more importantly, they were being designed with telephonic capabilities in mind. In one of the new patent reports that we posted yesterday, we pointed to Apple describing future video glasses that would integrate hidden audio sensors within the glass or frame to enhance voice commands capabilities. Little did we know that the best data was yet to come. Late last night, Patently Apple discovered a powerful new patent application that details some rather interesting features that Apple is considering for a future headset. Perhaps that Glass War that we described last month is going to be a lot more interesting than we initially thought.

Topic.Title: Four Apple Execs Got A Big Raise When Scott Forstall Was Canned

Message.Msg: And Scott should have signed the apology because if one day Apple will ask its customers to give up Google search for Apple search, then the customer better be able to trust it is as good or better than Google. The Maps program at launch was not as good or better and because of that a lot of people have moved on from it, and that's unfortunate because its slowly but surely improving. In my area the 3D view is lifelike and useful, but I know most people live in areas where they will not yet be able to appreciate it. Also, Maps is a way to enter the local search market. Google does not dominate this market and it is very fragmented. It is important that Apple get new categories right the first time. Trust is key going forward or people will quickly move on. Scott should have apologized. The fact that he refused suggest that he did not and does not get it. Tim Cook showed that he is a wise executive by firing Scott. It proves he knows how to zone in on the key variable. That's one of the things Steve did so well. It's a really important quality if you hope to stay ahead.

Message.Title: Jefferies Misek Sour On Apple
Message.Msg: “Apple's capital expenditures are likely to double in the next two years (adding $10 billion per year, he estimates) as the company is forced to finance its chip and touchscreen suppliers' factory expansions and build up its iCloud and online service centers.” “Apple's cash balance could be reduced by $10 billion, and $40 billion of the company's cash collections could be deferred over the next two years if Apple plans to expand its iPhone sales into pre-pay countries like India by replacing its carrier subsidy model with an arrangement where it lends the money to buy the phones directly to consumers” “International iPhone sales are slowing dramatically," Misek writes, "particularly in lower GDP per capita markets. We believe alternative distribution models like those in India can improve growth and the financing receivables will largely be securitizable; however, increased capital commitments would make a quick change more difficult should sales fall." “The rise in so-called whitebox smartphones sales will accentuate what he calls "Apple's product gap." He points to Glonee and Konka, both of which he says are offering handsets that are similar to the Samsung Galaxy S3 but for a fraction of the price. "We think these high-end white box phones are forcing Apple to invest in next-gen screen technology in order to differentiate."

Topic.Title: Public school teacher here. All my "cool" students have Samsungs, make fun of "nerds" with iPhones.

Message.Msg: DENVER (AP) — The days of lugging around 500-page playbooks and stacks of DVDs are over for half of the players in the NFL. Their teams have gone digital, replacing the old-fashioned thick paper playbooks with iPads that put everything from X's and O's to notifications, scouting reports and video cut-ups at their fingertips. "Technology is taking over the world and we're just trying to keep up with it," Green Bay Packers backup quarterback Graham Harrell said. The number of teams using iPads for playbooks and game film has increased this season from two to 14. In the NFC, the Bears, Cardinals, Cowboys, Lions, Packers, Panthers, Redskins and Seahawks are using the tablets as are the Bengals, Broncos, Chargers, Colts, Dolphins and Ravens in the AFC.

Message.Title: schaeffers research sees limited upside until May after Q2 Miss
Message.Msg: "Calls have emerged as the options of choice on AAPL today, with around 142,000 contracts crossing the tape. By comparison, roughly 102,000 puts have changed hands. One speculator used a portion of these calls to construct a credit spread (or short call spread) in the stock's April-dated series of options. At 10:15 a.m. ET on the International Securities Exchange (ISE), one block of 1,000 April 485 calls traded near the ask price for $5.57, while a symmetrical block of April 480 calls simultaneously crossed closer to the bid price for $6.52, resulting in a net credit of $0.95. By constructing this neutral-to-bearishly skewed strategy, the speculator will profit as long as AAPL remains south of breakeven at $480.95 (sold strike plus net credit) through April expiration. However, the maximum reward is limited to $0.95, regardless of how far the stock may fall over the next eight weeks. Should AAPL muscle higher in that time frame, the most this trader stands to lose is $4.05 per contract (the difference between the two strikes minus the net credit received).

Topic.Title: Buy the steak, and hold AAPL for the coming sizzles.

Message.Msg: I'm convinced AAPL will have a significant rally in 2013. The possibilities of big "sizzles" arising from headline news depicting "disruptive innovations" could propel AAPL to new highs. In my view, it's inevitable. In the meantime, buying the "Steak" is, by any measure, a superior investment and AAPL's metrics have created a "floor" beneath the stock. For example: √ Its balance sheet shows some $137 billion in cash which translates to more than $100 per share √ Its P/E of around 10 is below its sector, and way below Google's P/E of 24.77 √ Its current dividend yield of about 2.4% (which is likely to increase) pays investors to be patient, and there are continuing "whispers" of a possible stock split of 10:1.

Message.Msg: Because it is a very expensive, half-baked idea. It has Segway written all over it. Something that gets a lot of pre-release hype but then fizzles and became the butt of jokes when it hits the market. Who wants to walk around with frameless glasses and a tiny computer strapped to their head that you talk to and does little more than take #$%$ photos? Especially when you can just take a phone out of your pocket in times of need that does everything much better and doesn't make you look like a complete dork. In the future perhaps technology will advance far enough that computer glasses make sense. For now, though, it is just the kind of thing that should remain in R&D labs.

Topic.Title: Lowest volumn of the year

Message.Msg: they had the 2 for 1 chance yesterday to increase volume today. what's wrong with this new untested management team? ``Apple (AAPL) Trading Volume Shrivels; Is it Time to Reconsider a Stock Split? January 31, 2013 12:18 PM EST There's something notable going on with Apple's (NASDAQ: AAPL) stock over the past few days and it has traders talking. Volume over the past few sessions has been anemic. Normally trading 22.1 million shares on an average day, Apple volume fell 27 percent yesterday to 14,887,300. Today volume was only 4,750,000 shares at noon. At this pace shares will only exchange hands about 12 million times for the full day. Some might view the lower volume as positive sign - suggesting sellers have dried up. Others might view it as a negative sign - with buyers failing to step-up even with shares trading at a 35 discount to its September highs. One thing management can takeaway from the lower volume is a need to re-evaluate a stock split. In the past CEO Tim Cook laughed-off the idea of a stock split, essentially calling them stupid. Nonetheless, a split could bring in a new round of investors - something Apple desperately needs. Recently another split-adverse company - salesforce (NYSE: CRM) - bit the bullet and is now seeking shareholder approval for a 4-for-1 split. salesforce said a Stock Split would make shares more affordable and attractive to a broader group of potential investors, increase liquidity in the trading of its common stock and increase the attractiveness of our employee equity awards. Apple should take note and follow suit.``

Topic.Title: Selling/Shorting below $450

Message.Msg: $700 was great or even $500... What the hell, I am in at $460 so don't start throwing books at me. But, if you don't cover near $450 then you are absolutely delusional and deserve to lose most of your profit on a few big pops. Catching high or low can be your good investment or luck but if you don't take the profits off the table when it's huge then you still need some more books... If I was a short, I will cover when there is blood on the streets. And, in terms of apple share price, that's what it is. $450 is absolutely depressed price and one should not be short here in any condition unless you have trillions to move the stock down even further.... I don't give advice but it seems ridiculously low price for AAPL and if someone is still shorting here, they deserve the punishment.

Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) Forces Executives to Own Stock; Cook Must Hold 10x His Salary Apple (AAPL) Forces Executives to Own Stock; Cook Must Hold 10x His Salary Dow Nears All-Time High, But Longer Wait Possible on Sequester (DIA) U.S. Economy Grows Fractionally in Q4 Leap (LEAP) May End Up with Glut of Unsold iPhones (AAPL) February 28, 2013 3:39 PM EST Get Alerts AAPL Hot Sheet Price: $444.79 +0.05% Overall Analyst Rating: BUY ( Down) Dividend Yield: 2.3% Revenue Growth %: +17.7% Despite earlier opposition, Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) has implemented a change to its corporate governance policy that could ruffle a few feathers in Cupertino, California. Apple is now requiring executive officers to hold 3x their annual base salary in stock. The CEO is required to hold 10x his annual base salary in stock and Non-Employee Directors are required to hold 5x their annual retainer. In the past, Apple was criticized for failing to implement executive share ownership guidelines. Of note, Apple stock has declined by approximately 37 percent since reaching an all time highs at $705 per share in September 2012, so any little change could help.

Message.Title: The Board Has Some Splain' To Do Lucy
Message.Msg: Apple Required Executives to Hold Triple Their Salary in Stock BY JESSICA E. LESSIN AND JOANN S. LUBLIN Apple Inc. earlier this month reversed its stance on a corporate-governance measure related to executive compensation, implementing a new rule that executives must hold triple their base salary in company stock. The move, which hasn't previously been reported, came even though a month earlier Apple's board urged shareholders to oppose a very similar corporate-governance measure proposed by a shareholder. Apple's new executive-stock-holding requirement was implemented Feb 6., according to a notice of the policy under a "corporate governance" tab on its website. The date was about a month after the company issued its proxy statement and three weeks before Wednesday's AGM. .

Topic.Title: Apple Call options question

Message.Msg: You're still making a big assumption that it'll get called away. It won't. Given the premium is $65 and expiry close to 2 years away, it is highly unlikely that it'll get called away with so much time left before expiry and with that big of a premium on it. Think about if you made that trade. If you bought a $450 call at $65, it would have to be at $515 for you to break even when exercising the option. Nobody is going to do that until it is well above $515.

Topic.Title: Apple Call options question

Message.Msg: Susan, Look at it in a different way. Do you honestly believe that Apple will rise in value in any meaningful way from this point. If the answer is no, then you should sell your 100 shares and use $44,100 that you receive and work with that. If you don't think it will rise, then take $10,000 and buy some leaps or long term in the money puts. That will be your total risk and the potential for reward is far greater than what you could do with buying the stock. If you think that maybe it will rise but are not sure, buy long term puts and calls both in the money. If it falls apart you will do fine and if by some myrical it rises you will also do well.

Message.Title: PUCK YOU! Management Hold MY BAGS Now @ The Open YOU CREEPS
Message.Msg: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) executives must hold triple their base salary in company stock, according to a new rule the iPhone maker introduced earlier this month and was detailed in a corporate governance notice on its website. The requirement was implemented on February 6, according to The Wall Street Journal. Executive officers will have five years to satisfy the requirement. The company’s chief executive officer would have to hold 10 times the annual base salary, while board directors would need to hold five times their annual retainer. The rule is extremely interesting because the company recommended investors oppose a very similar measure proposed by an individual shareholder at the annual meeting this week. That proposal was supported by the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the biggest U.S. public pension fund, but failed to pass after garnering only 29.7 percent of the tallied votes. The measure was introduced by corporate governance advocate James McRitchie, who asked that Apple executives retain 33 percent of shares acquired through pay-equity programs “until reaching normal retirement age.” But through its proxy for the meeting, Apple asked shareholders to vote against the measure because it had the potential of “undermin[ing] the company’s ability to attract and retain executives” while providing “no benefit to the company”…

Topic.Title: Apple Call options question

Message.Msg: I'm not sure your broker has that right, or you're not explaining what he said accurately. If your shares get called away, you'll be down on your call as much if not more than what you'll be up in the stock (depending on how much time is left on the contract). You only keep the premium you sold if the option expires worthless or you buy it back at a lower price (i.e. if the stock continues to slide from here and next month that Jan 2015 550 call is only $45). If you get called away, you're essentially selling your shares for the same price as the strike you were selling calls for. So in this case you'd be selling your 100 shares @ 550 to the person that exercised the call you sold. If that were the case, you'd end up with the follow: 550 * 100 shares = 55000 55000 + 3000 = 58000 By taking his advice, the worst case is you get called away from your shares and you essentially "break even" on the underlying shares while pocketing the $3000 you have already cashed in on from selling call options. The best case scenario is the stock stays under 550 and you keep your shares, pocket the premium from selling the Jan 2015 550 call along with the $3000 you've already banked. This seems unlikely to me since the stock has 20+ months to move more than $100. Even if it moved half of that amount in the next 2-3 months, the price of that option will likely be greater than what you sold it for...meaning you'd be under water on the covered call, but your shares would also be up. Personally, I wouldn't sell leaps. The purpose of selling covered calls is to collect premium as often as you can in order to lower your overall cost basis. Ideally, if you're an active trader, you sell out of the money weeklies where time decay works faster for you. You can be aggressive and sell 2-3 strikes out of the money for a few hundred in premium every week, or you can play it more conservatively and sell 4+ strikes out of the money for $50 a week. Hope that helps, and good luck to you.

Topic.Title: Apple Call options question

Message.Msg: TOO bad you did not read down and find out she was talking about $450 call not $550. As others said no one will call that option unless it goes into the money at strike plus premium which would currently be $515. To put it simply if she writes the call and then does nothing else she receives $6500 now, she already got $3,000 and assuming that the price rise above $450 in the next 2 years she then would receive $45,000. She would then have received a total of $54,500. Her investment was $50,000. So that scenario means hold for 2 years to realize a $500 loss. HOWEVER there is a very big risk that Apple will never come back to above $450. If the stock drops to $300 over the next 2 years she will have to buy the option back for maybe $10 and then effectively only get $29,000 plus $9,500 back loosing the difference of $55,000 less $38,500 or $16,500. Better to sell now with a $10,000 loss

Topic.Title: Aapl's Innovation Days Are Done

Message.Msg: BOA Merill Lynch Swap Out Of Apple And Into Samsung On Lack Of Innovation @ MWC Samsung could be the new Apple, analysts say Matthew Braga | Feb 28, 2013 11:28 AM ET Samsung Electronics Co. could be on track to become the next Apple Inc., analysts say, pointing to a slew of new, “compelling” product announcements at Mobile World Congress (MWC) as proof of the iPhone maker’s declining penchant for innovation. In a report from Bank of America Merill Lynch released Thursday morning, analysts were intrigued by the “replacement of Apple by Samsung,” as Chinese device manufacturers such as Huawei Technology Co., Ltd. and ZTE Corp. now appear to be cribbing from the Samsung’s designs and feature sets instead. Samsung announced a number of new products at MWC, held annually in Barcelona, including the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 – the Korean electronics giant’s answer to the iPad Mini, released last year. “We believe Apple’s recent products, the iPhone 5 and the iPad Mini simply can’t stand next to the innovation and buzz Samsung has brought to the market,” the report reads. Merill Lynch analysts predicted that Samsung’s growing mobile busness, in addition to the strength of traditional businesses such as flash memory production and high-definition TVs, would translate into “solid earnings momentum” for investors.

Message.Title: Samsung hires British judge who said Apple lacked integrity
Message.Msg: Samsung hires British judge who said Apple lacked integrity By Philip Elmer­DeWitt February 28, 2013: 7:45 AM ET Sir Robin Jacob issued harsh sanctions after Apple's half­hearted "not as cool" apology FORTUNE ­­ Remember the British case that Apple lost to Samsung last July in which the judge ordered Apple to publish a notice in newspapers and on its website correcting the impression left by the trial that Samsung's Galaxy tablets had copied the iPad? It's back in the news, with a twist. Apple (AAPL), you may recall, complied with the unusual order, but in such a passive aggressive way ­­ adding its own marketing spin to the court's language and quoting the judge as saying Samsung's devices were "not as cool" as the iPad ­­ that a judge in London's highest court threw the book at them. Sir Robin Jacob admonished Apple in the strongest terms, ordering it to pay Samsung's legal fees on an "indemnity basis" (i.e. all possible costs, including parking, phone calls, etc. from day one), and spelling out precisely where Apple, in the language it added, basically lied. "I hope," Sir Robin wrote at the end of his ruling, "that the lack of integrity involved in this incident is entirely atypical of Apple." Here's the twist: Samsung has hired him as an expert witness. "I'm sure that Samsung and Sir Robin Jacob wouldn't be doing this if there was any risk of this conduct violating the law," writes FOSS Patents' Florian Mueller, who stumbled across Sir Robin's name in the expert list in a separate case before the ITC. But, Mueller adds: "For someone so concerned with 'integrity,' it is utterly unusual to issue a high ­profile and extreme ruling in favor of a particular party (Samsung in this case) only to be hired as an expert by that same party in another dispute.

Topic.Title: Apple Call options question

Message.Msg: Selling the 450 strike is worse advice in my opinion. As you said, she would be tying up that money in AAPL shares for two years just to book a $500 loss overall if she was called away. I do have a question about your numbers though. You mention if the stock drops to $300 over the time of the contract (2 years), she would have to buy the option back. Why? Just let the thing expire since it's so far out of the money. If that happened, she would have $30000 (100 shares * $300) plus $3000 from earlier covered calls plus $6500 from the 450 call that would be expiring for a total of $39500, not $38500. Regardless, your conclusion is valid if we're thinking AAPL is done for. Personally, I'm a believer that AAPL will find new ways to innovate and eventually the stock will have new revenue streams for growth in addition to existing revenue streams (iPods, iPads, iPhones, etc). So to me, it makes sense to hang on to those 100 shares as long as possible and collect premiums by selling calls more often than once every two years (gradually lowering the cost basis in the process).

Message.Title: Option question for longs
Message.Msg: This is what I believe. Apple will be greater than 550 by jan 2014 (conservative estimate). If I was to believe this, I want to play with two call options. 1. Buy a long call with jan 2014 expiration, strike price $400 ......the call is priced at close to $60. I can buy 10 contracts at most based on my liquidity (very close to being in the money at expiration) 2. Buy 30 contract for strike price of $500 for about $20 or so with same expiration. Basically stock has to rise above 520 at expiration for any value Call (1) more closely tracks the stock price, call number 2 tracks it less (for example today, stock price fell by $3.17 and call option price for (1) fell by $3.15 and for call option (2) price fell by $1.5 or so...... What is your recommendation on which option play. I am leaning on option 1..... I am not holding the call option to expiry and will probably sell it if the stock gets a 100 point pop by early q4. Your sage advice is greatly appreciated, there is enough open interest on both options so liquidity is not an issue.

Message.Title: Apple in the Home & on the Road
Message.Msg: Samsung is making huge strides towards dominating the mobile arena but they don't have Apple's ecosphere (iTunes...) Samsung does however have a strong presence in the home with television & kitchen appliances which presents them with the opportunity to develop connectivity in an area which I believe Apple should pursue aggressively (in fact Apple is selling Nest smart thermostats in the Apple store which indicates they are aware of the importance of networking with home appliances.) Instead of all the brouhaha about increased dividends (Einhorn is a punk) I'd like to see them buy LG ($13.6B market cap) (as an aside LG makes glass which competes with GLW's product) or better yet GE's appliance production division (value unsure - GE unsuccessfully tried to sell this division back in 2008 & wound up using Toyota's Total Production System to revamp their Louisville ops instead.) Last year Apple announced partnerships with: BMW, General Motors, Mercedes-Benz, Land Rover, Jaguar, Audi, Toyota, Chrysler & Honda to introduce iOS & Siri & I can't find a whole lot of info on how this is progressing. (Maybe I should visit a few car lots...) Anyways; I paired up (long) with AAPL & GLW since Corning provides glass for iOS & Android products (in addition to being the proven leader in high tech glass display & laboratory products.) Intel would probably be another pair trade but I just can't seem to make myself do it. Anyone got any semi solid rumors/factoids about AAPL? Oh; I switched from a Microsoft brick to a MacBook Pro a little over a year ago & now iHappy.

Topic.Title: Option question for longs

Message.Msg: It entirely depends on your strategy. Dont look at the deltas right not, those are way too far away anyway. The 400s, being deep ITM, are a safer bet, in the sense that its unlikely you will lose 100% of your money. With out the money calls, your hoping the stock moves up a lot more just to break even, or 520 (18% from 440). It might not sound like a lot, given you have a good 9 months, but if this stock continues to be a dog like right now, you can lose that 60k really fast. I am a risk taker however, and would personally buy about 1/3 my position, at the 500 strike. But if I were to give anyone advice, I say do 1/3rd with the 400. To make yourself feel better, maybe have split it half 400 and half 500, that way your playing it safe, and can reap big gains if you are right on the movement. Remember, BUY IN INCREMENTS. Just like shares, if you do follow this strategy, your chances of coming up even BIGGER is lifted substantially. I think you are on the money though with this, 550 seems like a good estimate for jan '14.

Topic.Title: Option question for longs

Message.Msg: Options trading is not for the faint of heart and remember, you can lose your entire investment. It's common. That said, I would never recommend buying out of the money calls. It's pay off is certainly higher but the reward rarely justifies the risk. Granted, I think it's likely AAPL exceeds 520 by Jan 2014 but we're way lower than any rational being a year ago thought we would be at this point. So I would lean toward buying the $400 option at $60. That cost you $60K but at 460 you're even and at 520 you have another $60K IF it gets there. Another consideration is to but the 400 call and sell 10C call at $500 for the $20. You get $20K to defray your $60K so now you're basically at intrinsic value (i.e., you control the contracts for $40K and the stock is trading at 441 so you're actually $1K to the good. If the stock runs to $500, you've capped your gain at $60 but if it doesn't get that high, you're maximum exposure is $40K and anything above 440 you keep the difference in gain. If the stock goes above 500, you still only get 500 when the option expires. You might want to try using just 1 contract instead of 10 until you are confident. Remember to trade to trade another day. Good luck.
